awd_titl_txt: Automated Large-Scale Phonetic Analysis: DASS Pilot
awd_abstract_narration:
Generalizations about language contained in dictionaries and grammars hide the extensive variation in the way that speakers actually use language. However, modern technology now makes it possible to use automated means to extract variation in pronunciation from spoken interviews. This research project uses available software to process sixty-four interviews with speakers from Florida, Georgia, Tennessee, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Texas recorded from 1968-1983. These interviews constitute a geographic and social sample of speakers across the Gulf States. All of the transcriptions of the interviews, the vowel pronunciation data, and the visualizations will be presented on the website of the Linguistic Atlas Project. Detailed data on actual speaker variation addresses the industrial methods currently used for speech recognition and speech synthesis.

This project will be the first large-scale test of the complex systems model against acoustic phonetic data. The legacy interviews consist of over 200 Gb of files containing 372 hours of digital audio interviews. In the first stage of the research, vowel pronunciations will be extracted from a list of seventy-eight different words that were elicitation targets in the interviews, plus additional words found to occur frequently in the interviews such as color terms, up to a total of three hundred words. The resulting data set will have approximately 22,500 vowel tokens per interview, nearly 1,500,000 tokens across the data set, a very large corpus of data on Southern American English. The second stage of the project will create visualizations of these tokens to determine the dimensions of variation in the realization of vowels per speaker, social category, and geographic area. The science of complex systems will be employed as a model in the analysis, which predicts that the wide range of realizations that occurs in the groups under analysis will be self-organized into nonlinear distributional patterns. The extraction and display of the full range of vowel variation has the potential to improve industrial methods used for both speech recognition and speech synthesis, as it offers a detailed view of actual variation for speakers and groups rather than assuming a consistent or ?average? realization of vowels.

por.por_cntn:
This project has produced transcriptions for nearly 400 hours of audio linguistic interviews, with 64 people across 8 states in the Southeastern USA (Georgia, Florida, Tennessee, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, Texas). The interviews, known as the Digital Archive of Southern Speech, were gathered from 1968 - 1983. The transcriptions include two million spoken words, which are indexed directly to their audio files, facilitating analysis of the acoustics of individual speech sounds. The output provides an oral historical snapshot of language and life in the US South among people born between 1886 and 1965. 


Results from acoustic data have shed light on spoken-language variation in the historical US South, including across ethnic groups, generations, genders, and geographic sub-regions. Analyses have included data from vowels, consonants, and intonational prosody. Data was gathered at multiple time-points per vowel to capture trajectories through acoustic space. Considering differences from the oldest to youngest speakers, trajectory data show the progression of changes in vowel pronunciation that contribute to the distinctive regional accent found in the US South. Generally, the strongest evidence of stereotypical Southern pronunciation patterns comes from European American women. Trajectory analysis also found evidence of distinct speech patterns across races: speakers who are African American vs. European American have systematically different vowel characteristics. Analysis of vowel acoustics found evidence of extensive variation, and non-uniformity, in pronunciation across speakers throughout the South. For example, analysis with GIS mapping techniques shows that speakers in the Mississippi River Delta, centered around New Orleans, adhere to fewer norms of Southern speech.


The project also introduced novel large-scale analysis of vowels using point pattern analysis, a technique from GIS. This technique demonstrated that the nonlinear frequency profile predicted by a complex systems approach appears at every level of analysis (individual speaker, group, etc.). Such findings do not support the idea of regular change over time or across population groups, such as the Southern Shift or the notion of a regular, separate African American pronunciation pattern. Analysis using point pattern analysis greatly complicates the traditional account of vowel systems and change over time. 


From a technical standpoint, the project demonstrated the successful application, to "legacy" recordings, of tools for automatically aligning transcriptions with audio. The alignments produce a high degree of accuracy: by checking over 10,000 individual tokens, we have found that approximately 86% of transcribed words are correctly aligned with the corresponding audio. The data produced by this project can have an impact on fields related to linguistics including computer science, speech and hearing sciences, acoustics, and electrical engineering. This large-scale corpus is available to the general public and to all researchers who want to work with speech in order to train and test software for automatic speech recognition, speech synthesis, or studies of speech perception. The release includes the full text of the corpus, speaker biographies, full audio files, individual speakers' interviews in .txt and .xml format, and Praat TextGrids containing force-aligned information about segmental content. Acoustic information can be viewed and used to generate downloadable graphics via the Gazetteer of Southern Vowels. 


This project provided research experience and opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Georgia. Approximately 70 students were supported by NSF's Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, to carry out transcriptions, assist with data-checking, and analysis. Several undergraduate honors theses and publications have been based on this project. Additionally, the project supported seven graduate students through a portion of their PhD training in Linguistics: these students managed undergraduate REUs, developed our pipeline for transcription and data analysis pipeline, and used the output of this project in their own thesis research, working under the direct mentorship of the PIs.
